The text fills the face of the stone, with a margin of 10mm on the left edge, and a margin along the top of 22mm. The first two lines are larger than the rest.

Second or earlier first century BCE, primarily on palaeographic grounds (Manganaro various proposed dates between the end of 2nd century BCE and end of 1st century BCE (Manganaro 1963 and Cebeillac Gervasoni suggest post 36 BCE, assuming that line 17 implies the status of Centuripe as Latin municipium, which seems doubtful); Dubois, IGDS, suggests early 2nd century).

Cadastral inscription for the territory of Halaesa

2nd — 1st century BCE (Kaibel simply 'post-Roman conquest'; Calderone argues 2nd — 1st on letter forms etc. of his frag.; but, 1998, for c. 300 BCE, which Nenci too believes; Manganaro 2nd century BCE).

Three lines of large letters across the upper part of one of the wider faces. The inscribed field is approximately 0.36 m high x 0.30 m wide. The first line of text is less clear, especially around the upper margin and at the right edge. A continuous horizontal line separates lines 1 and 2.

The letters are engraved in broad, rounded strokes (partly the result of weathering) and have a regular form. K has arms that do not quite reach to the top and bottom of the letter; E has strokes of equal length; A has broken bar. The text is either Latin or a mixture or Latin and Greek, given the presence of L in the second line.
Photo J. Prag, courtesy Museo Archeologico Regionale di Adrano
